newsitem.title: USA: Indian nuclear treaty concerns can be met - Clinton.
newsitem.headline: Indian nuclear treaty concerns can be met - Clinton.

text.p: President Bill Clinton on Tuesday hailed the UN General Assembly approval of a treaty to bar nuclear explosions and said the concerns of India, which says it will block it, could be addressed.

"With this treaty we are on the verge of realizing a decades old dream that no nuclear weapons will be detonated anywhere on the the face of the earth," Clinton said during a stop on his campaign for the Nov. 5 presidential election.

"I believe we can find a way for the Indians to have their security concerns met," Clinton said. India, whose signature is necessary, has vowed to block the treaty ratification, saying the treaty does not go far enough in spelling out a timetable for global nuclear disarmament.
India also maintains that the treaty would prevent it from responding to threats from neighbouring China and from Pakistan, which may have a covert nuclear and missile program.
The U.N. voted 158-to-3 in favor of the treaty, which bans all nuclear weapons explosions, in the atmosphere or underground, and sets up a monitoring system to verify compliance or spot violations.
"Together the United States and the nations of the world have taken another giant step toward making our world safer," Clinton told reporters.
